@proffesorzack there’s a difference between a compliment at an appropriate time in an appropriate situation, and what’s depicted in this video. The woman walking down the street has no idea what intentions the man catcalling her has, and so many of us have had bad/scary experiences that have started with a simple “compliment”. Women have been conditioned to have our guards up, and what you perceive to be a simple compliment towards a complete stranger could actually be something that makes her very uncomfortable.

@alexanderwindh The stereotype is not, nor has it ever been, that all men in this earth are toxic. That said, there is an overwhelming amount who are. It’s not that all men are toxic, it’s that the ones who are toxic are louder. They’re in the forefront. They’re abrasive and are perpetuating the idea that this behaviour is normal. Gillette is applauding the “other” and trying to bring THEM to the forefront. It’s telling the good ones to be louder than the bad ones. If you’re not one of these toxic men, this commercial is literally celebrating you.
@_copperboom the stereotype is that most men are like this.  And it's bs
@alexanderwindh the ad very clearly celebrates “the good ones”. It doesn’t condemn men in general, it condemns the toxic stereotypes.

@the_noah_afualo ...but it also very clearly celebrates “good” men. It doesn’t condemn all men whatsoever. If it was paining all men by the same brush, the ending of the commercial would have been entirely different.

@playboy_heffy this commercial showed examples of toxic masculinity AND kind, sensitive, warm men. I personally don’t see how it’s a sexist attack ad. 🤷🏼‍♀️ As a woman, I fully expect to be held accountable for my own actions (though, sometimes society wants us to be held accountable for the actions of others). I wouldn’t feel any differently about this ad had it been centred around women. It celebrates men who go against the stereotypes. It celebrates the “others”. It celebrates kindness and empathy. It isn’t attacking good men, it’s condemning the bad ones and condemning the societal expectations that men need to be tough, rough, borderline mean, bad boys.

@proffesorzack There's a difference between a harmless, genuine compliment and a comment that actually feels threatening, or feels as if it there was another agenda behind it. A simple "you look pretty" isn't the issue. The issue is when it becomes sexual, or is said in a way that is threatening or makes one feel unsafe/uncomfortable. Something along the lines of "nice arse" from a stranger is rude and usually makes people feel unsafe

@fadeelah_williams I think you're wrong there - maybe because you don't identify with the group bring stereotyped. But the fact you think such an ad would be ok 'if done right' highlights where we differ. I think that grouping people by race, gender or whatever to present some narrative is wrong and promotes prejudice. There is no doing it right. If you want to fight violence or harassment or whatever tackle the acts themselves and the individual perpetrators. I thought most would agree but this whole thing has proven me wrong.
i agree with the message i don’t agree with companies trying to sell their sh*t using these messages. too deep and too intense for an ad.
@fadeelah_williams advertisements often do involve generalizations but there's a big difference between generalizations and discrimination and I honestly think you're confusing the too

@tommieinthemiddle honestly if the ad was done right I don't think if I would be angry because let's say the ad was from the perspective of black person living in the black neighborhood appealing to their neighbors to stop the mugging and or gang violence I doubt I would be offended especially because their are many as like this already existing . It really depends specifically on the nature of the ad for example if it had condescending or racist tones etc.

@fadeelah_williams On this 2nd point, this same argument could be applied to an ad asking black people  to hold each other accountable for mugging.  Just trying to address those black people who mug people. Would this be ok with you? Genuinely curious.

@fadeelah_williams Fair enough. I guess it's convenient to ignore sexism when its against the other gender. I'm sure I've been guilty of that. I guess I'm here to point it out here. Best way to deal with violence etc. including culturally, is to punish and shame perpetrators - not group people and blame genders, races etc.
@fadeelah_williams specifically the grown men who do exhibit those behaviour traits*

@fadeelah_williams and sure not all men exhibit these behaviour traits (in fact the ad makes point to praise the men who dont) but no matter how you look at it the ads intention was clearly stated to be to teach grown men to be better and to show young men what behaviour is unacceptable and in that it succeeded

@tommieinthemiddle The ad may be a little sexist towards men (even though I don't think it does your argument does have some grounds) most people are not applauding it for its alleged sexist nature we are applauding the ad because it acts as another step towards dismantling the societal enforced negative behaviour traits such as sexual misconduct and violence which many men live by unpunished and without any social consequence.

@fadeelah_williams I'm not saying women don't suffer sexism (I doubt though you'll find ads holding women as a group accountable for shitty behaviour) - what I'm saying is that it's disappointing after supporting efforts to fight sexism against women, that as soon as a clear case against men comes up all the women applaud it and mock men who call it out for what it is. That's the kind of thing you all hate sexist men for. Hypocrisy.
@tommieinthemiddle let me direct you to every woman deodorant soap and or beauty product commercial ever

The ad is sexist. If you can't see that, you don't know what sexist is. Taking the negative behaviour of a small number of people and then holding a much much larger group collectively accountable simply because they share a gender with those people is sexist. If an ad came out asking black people to stop each other mugging people would you be saying "I don't get it - they're just asking black people to be decent human beings!" Check yourselves.

The ad is sexist. If you can't see that, you don't know what sexist is. Taking the negative behaviour of a small number of people and then holding a much much larger group collectively accountable simply because they share a gender with those people is sexist. What is wrong with you all? How can you not see this? If an ad came out asking black people to stop each other mugging people would you be saying "I don't get it - they're just asking black people to be decent human beings!" Check yourselves.
